Dear Age 61 &Active,

Aortic stenosis is a common valve disease among elderly patients and it can be serious, without a cure or even a maintenance drug on the horizon. Compared to mitral valve disease, which is more common among women and younger women, aortic valve disease is more common among men older than 60. As you know, the aortic valve lies between the left ventricle of the heart and the aorta that distributes blood throughout the body: it is the valve you feel as you put your hand over your chest bone and listen to a murmur.

The most frequent cause of aortic stenosis is “calcific aortic stenosis,” in which a process of calcification of the valve leads to the valve leaflets to come together – like hands cupping, or coming together as you squeeze a tennis ball. A slightly less commonly encountered cause of aortic obstruction is a rotary valve motion disorder, in which the valve lobes spin instead of opening up, leading to a Doppler systolic click under the valve. Finally, milder degrees of aortic stenosis may result from what’s called “primary aorta regurgitation”: the aortic root,

—S.

Aortic stenosis, also called aortic valve stenosis, is a condition in which the blood-flow in or out of the heart is blocked due to a narrowed aortic valve. The aortic valve is a critical organ through which the chambers of the heart (ventricles) pump blood into the extra 7 billions capillaries throughout the body that carry nutrients to all the cells.

A normal aortic valve has three leaflets.  A well-working aortic valve is also able to adapt its size to the amount of blood being pumped out by the heart.

Aortic stenosis is caused by a narrowed aortic valve and can occur for various reasons. These include:

- Calcification, in which calcium is secreted in the leaflets of the valve, (the affected segments get stiffer)
- Genetic defects that in the ability of the valve’s internal leaflets to adapt
- Problems with a heart valve from a previous heart operation or congenital heart disease (birth defects).
- Structural problems (Various reasons such as infectious processes, mitral valve prolapse, and rheumatic fever are found to possess risk for aortic stenosis later in life)

As aortic stenosis progresses the body will adjust by speeding up the heart rate to compensate. The heart will often beat erratically to increase the output of blood-flow through what is available. Symptoms of aortic stenosis include exercise limitation, weakness, shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, palpitations (irregular or pounding heart beat), and fainting episodes.

The hardness of the calcification narrowing in aortic stenosis will take time to develop. Procedures can be done to widen the narrowed valve or even replace the defective valve. Depending on the degree of heart failure, patients who can not get better can urgently require an emergency operation to prevent death.

Aortic stenosis is best identified “accidentally” through medical screening procedures, electrocardiograms (ECGs) or echocardiograms (ultrasound heart scan). The actual fact of aort

Aortic stenosis happens when the opening in the aortic valve becomes narrower because of calcium build-up. When the valve doesn’t open as well, blood has a harder time flowing through the valve and the rest of the body. The valve becomes too hard for the heart to pump all the blood it needs through the body, and, over time, the heart becomes weak.

If aortic stenosis is left untreated, the pressure on the heart to make sure it pumps blood properly to the rest of the body can cause the heart to swell, press down on the body structures around it, and eventually stop working.

For women age 80 and over, aortic stenosis is the most common acquired heart defect.

### What are the risk factors for aortic stenosis?

- Age
- Family history
- Congenital issues
- Rheumatic fever or rheumatoid arthritis
- High blood pressure
- Kidney or thyroid disease

### What are the signs/symptoms?

- Pain in the back and calves when walking/exertion
- Dizziness
- Chest and shoulder pain
- Weakness
- Heart murmur

If you experience any of these symptoms, it’s important to see a doctor immediately. If left untreated, aortic stenosis can be life-threatening. When discovered in early stages, aortic stenosis can be treated by medication, and, in some cases, surgery.

### What are the tests used to diagnose aortic stenosis?

- Physical examination (your doctor will listen with a stethoscope to check for a murmur in your chest)
- Blood tests (to rule out other causes of your symptoms)
- Echocardiogram (this test lets us see your heart structure and how it’s working; this will show us if your valves are abnormal)

### What can I do to help prevent aortic stenosis?

- Eat a heart healthy diet low in saturated fat and trans fat.
- Eat fruits and vegetables as part of a healthy diet.
- Maintain a healthy weight throughout your life so you don’t become overweight or obese.

Free_form_answer: You can get or transmit HIV only through specific activities. Most commonly, people get or transmit HIV through sexual behaviors and needle or syringe use. Only certain body fluids-blood, semen (cum), pre-seminal fluid (pre-cum), rectal fluids, vaginal fluids, and breast milk-from a person who has HIV can transmit HIV. These fluids must come in contact with a mucous membrane or damaged tissue or be directly injected into the bloodstream (from a needle or syringe) for transmission to occur. Mucous membranes are found inside the rectum, vagina, penis, and mouth. In extremely rare cases, HIV has been transmitted by Contact between broken skin, wounds, or mucous membranes and HIV-infected blood or blood-contaminated body fluids.
